Posts.Content: What a nice article regarding Trudy and her humor.  I had the pleasure of meeting Trudy recently at a gathering of some of our close friends.  What a joy to meet her.  I also have stage 4 breast cancer and was very down at the time.  Trudy was undergoing Chemo treatments and was so positive and happy despite her treatment.  We just had a wonderful evening visiting and talking of other positive things.  Positive hope surely helps us all and especially those dealing with cancer.  Our disease is temporary and if we don't feel well during treatment, it does get better and sometimes a lot better.  We can get our appetite back!  We can get our hair back!! We can get out brain back!!  We can get our life back!!  Gail
Posts.Title: Re: Trudy with triple negative breast cancer

Posts.Content: On 5/22/2009 MomsGotCancer wrote: My mother was diagnosed with breast cancer about 6-8 weeks ago.  She has since had a double mastectomy, and was waiting till she was fully healed to start her Chemo.  She went to her oncologst yesterday, and they told her that it had spread to the bone.  First of all - why didn't they do this bone scan BEFORE they took her breasts - is that normal procedure?  Second - what are we to expect now?  What are the best meds for her to be on?  Any personal experiences are great appreciated.  I'm very lost right now, and don't know what to do/think. TIA - Sarah Yes, it seems it is common treatment.  I had left breast mastectomy...double saves trouble later.  I have had bone mets also and have been on Zometa for 3 years.  My diagnosis of the spread to the bone was 4 years ago.  I am having further spread now, but there is still suggested further treatment.  I actually have done quite well.  I also had chemo and radiation treatments for 6 months after my surgery.  I have taken Arimidex and have now been changed to Tamoxifen.  There is much that can be done.  Listen to your doctors.  Just find good ones at a good cancer center!!!  Keep positive as there is a lot of hope. Gail
Posts.Title: Breast to bone cancer - Very scared

Posts.Content: Mets to the bones is also treatable.  Just stay in touch with your doctors and monitor progress.  One girl I know is 10 year survivor with bone mets and still going strong.  Her example always keeps me encouraged,
Posts.Title: Mets to to bones;

Posts.Content: On 6/16/2007 Jennikmac wrote: I don't have any experience myself with Lymphedema but there is a girl in my support group who was just recently diagnosed with it.  She benefits from Lymphatic drainage massage; and also wears a compression sleeve.  She is young and a bit concerned about the fashion side of wearing a sleeve, but through some research on the internet found a place in San Fransico (I believe) that makes and sells "fashionable" compression sleeves.  I will ask her the exact link at our next meeting.  Apparently Lymphedema is a side effect that all of us who've had mastectomies run this risk of acquiring, and I've also been told that the risk is there for our entire lives.  At my breast cancer clinic (in Canada) there is a nurse who runs a "Lymphedema Clinic" in response to decades of complaints by those who've had mastectomies with no avenue for relief.  Ask your Onclologist if such a clinic exists in your area.  Hope this helps.  Let me know if you'd like the link.
Posts.Title: Lymphadema

Posts.Content: Yes, I have been there too. After 14 days I had lost all my hair.  I kind of had fun cutting off my long hair and making my own cut haircut instead of letting anyone else do it.  I covered my head with cute scarves and went with a friend to get a cute wig.  I matched it to my own hair before it came out.  Most shave their head, but I didn't.  Just cut my hair until it came out and then clipped the last little bit.  For me it made it not so bad. Here I am 2 years later with hair back allover my head and body.  I sure liked not having to shave my legs:)  But oh well, I just tried to keep a very positive outlook and go about my life as normal as possible.  There are so many medications now to help with all the side effects that I felt pretty good throughout my year of chemo treatments.  It was all worth it.  I feel a lot better now.  So you have a lot to look forward to.  Just be around encouraging people and good friends. Hope all goes very well for you. G
Posts.Title: hair lose and chemo effects

Posts.Content: Mary, So good to hear from so many getting treatment.  It is such encouragement to me also.  I have Stage IV Breast Cancer too and have tried Arimidex to Faslodex and nothing of those types seemed to help much.  I am now back on Chemo and taking Tamoxifen.  It is working.  I am a 6 l/2 year survivor and doing quite well although tired.  There are just so many options out there.  My doctors have been at MD Anderson in Houston, Texas and keep up to date.  Everyone just needs to get to the best doctors they can and follow their regimine.  People are living a long time these days. Gail  www.livingbyhope.com My featured website for the month of March will be MD Anderson
Posts.Title: Mom was just diagnosed with Stage IV Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: On Jan 07, 2011 4:45 PM BrittBaugh wrote: While i was home for Christmas we recieved a call from the doctor - my mom was diagnosed with Stage IV Breast Cancer. It's spread to her bones (spine, upper arms, collar bone, pelvis) and her liver. We had no clue...she had been sick since the summer - started with the small town doctor and he passed her on through the chain. She lost 15 lbs, had fevers for a month straight, and hurt all over. But noone could figure it out. They just knew something was wrong. Finally the kidney specialist sent her to the breast surgeron and that is who finally figured it out. This is still all new and i've been reading about it as much as I can. I don't know what I need to do to help her. I live 5 hours away and want to be there as much as possible. She hasn't started any treatment as of now and is still working. (she's a high school science teacher). The good news is she got into MD Anderson in TX and leaves on Jan 12th for her initial appt. What can I do as a daughter for her? My dad who is ubber stressed, and my two younger brothers? It's hard imagining my life without my mom and any inspiration would be great. I am so sorry to hear about your mother.  But I can tell you there is hope!!!  I also have Stage !V Breast Cancer and have survived now 6 and a half years.  I am now on a  new round of chemo and doing quite well.  Your mother is going to a good place and it does matter where you go.  I decided to start a website with my story and suggestions on quality care...one being MD Anderson.  I go to a center near Dallas, Texas and they are so positive and up-to-date on treatment.  My doctors have spent some time at MD Anderson. My website is www.livingbyhope.com Just be positive and supportive with your Mom.  There is wonderful help out there.  Take good care of yourself too!!!
Posts.Title: Mom was just diagnosed with Stage IV Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Mary, So good to hear from so many getting treatment.  It is such encouragement to me also.  I have Stage IV Breast Cancer too and have tried Arimidex to Faslodex and nothing of those types seemed to help much.  I am now back on Chemo and taking Tamoxifen.  It is working.  I am a 6 l/2 year survivor and doing quite well although tired.  There are just so many options out there.  My doctors have been at MD Anderson in Houston, Texas and keep up to date.  Everyone just needs to get to the best doctors they can and follow their regimine.  People are living a long time these days. Gail  www.livingbyhope.com My featured website for the month of March will be MD Anderson
Posts.Title: Mom was just diagnosed with Stage IV Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Two years after I began chemo treatment and a year after my mastectomy I am developing Lymphadema in my left arm.  Does anyone have experience with this and advice?? It is a little discouraging after going through so much else. But I sure want to work on this too.
Posts.Title: Lymphadema

Posts.Title: Mom was just diagnosed with Stage IV Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Is anyone else taking the new drug Xgeva?  I have taken my first injection.  It was very easy.  Had very little if any bone aches and don't seem to have any extreme side effects so far.  I have bone mets and was on Zometa for 5 years.  My doctor just changed me to Xgeva. I am also back on chemo as my tumor markers had gone up alarmingly.  They are now going down. Gail www.livingbyhope.com   My Featured website for March will be MD Anderson, Houston, Texas
Posts.Title: Xgeva

Posts.Content: Hi, I am so sorry for your diagnosis.  I too have Stage IV Breast Cancer with bone mets.  I have taken Zometa for 5 years and just had to stop for a while.  But I am now on Chemo for the third time.  Good news, it is working and I feel pretty good.  I am grateful that I am at a good comprehensive cancer center in the Dallas, Tx area.  Just go to the best place you can and even get a second and third opinion if necessary.  I did.  I am also taking supplements to boost the immune system. Don't give up.  It's worth the fight.  I am still going after 6 l/2 years. Take good care of yourself. My story is at www.livingbyhope.com  Gail
Posts.Title: diagnoised with stage iv breast cancer metastasized to bones in spine and pelvic

Posts.Content: Hi, I am so sorry for your diagnosis.  I too have Stage IV Breast Cancer with bone mets.  I have taken Zometa for 5 years and just had to stop for a while.  But I am now on Chemo for the third time.  Good news, it is working and I feel pretty good.  I am grateful that I am at a good comprehensive cancer center in the Dallas, Tx area.  Just go to the best place you can and even get a second and third opinion if necessary.  I did.  I am also taking supplements to boost the immune system. Don't give up.  It's worth the fight.  I am still going after 6 l/2 years. Take good care of yourself. My story is at www.livingbyhope.com  Gail
Posts.Title: diagnoised with stage iv breast cancer metastasized to bones in spine and pelvic

Posts.Content: I am s sorry to hear of your recent diagnosis.  I too have stage IV breast cancer.  I highly recommend going to a Comprehensive Cancer Center and getting a second opinion.  There are all kinds of new treatments out there.  Cancer Center of America never puts a date on how long you will live.  I have had stage IV for 4 years and know that a lot can be done.  A friend has cancer in lung and neck and was able to be treated and is doing fine.  She got it way before I did.  Some cancers are agressive, but with the correct chemo can be slowed down.  I wish you all the best, but please do not give up hope.  A positive attitude and aggressive action can go a long way.  I know,  my husband has been the most supportive along with close friends when I feel down.  Encourage friends to send her cards or phone calls.  Also encourage your wife if she is up to it to reach out to her friends and family.  Even sending them a card or a phone call.  Positive action helps so much.
Posts.Title: 2nd stage breast cancer now 4th stage lung cancer

Posts.Content: On 8/13/2009 map1749 wrote: We just got the most horrible news today. My wife's 2nd stage breast cancer has turned into 4th stage unoperable lung cancer! I am my wifes caregiver, her husband and dont know what to do. She had her breast cancer surgery on feb. 25 2009 which was very successful. The surgeon said he got all the cancer. She had 3 cancerous masses removed from her left breast and 3 lymph nodes. She soon developed a swelling in her breast and when we went to see the surgeon about he said that was normal. Several weeks went by and her breast was getting larger so we went to our family doctor and she also said that the swelling was normal. Her breast was 3 times the size of her other breast and they said that was normal? The following week I had to rush my wife to the hospital and she was experiencing pain in the breast. The surgeon at the emergency said it was a hemotoma and thus had to drain her breast. I was there when he did it.About a quart if fluid was drained from her breast. He said had she left it any longer it would have become infected. She had to delay her chemo beacuse of this hemotoma and she has had day care nureses coming to our home every 2nd day to repack the open wound and drain it.This has been going on since April-5 months! The wound his healing nicely so says the day care nurse. She started her 1st chemotherapy July 14 TC chemo. She received her 2nd chemo aug 4th. On august 11 she had difficulty breathing and had chest pains and was rushed by ambulance to the hospital. They did tests to see if she had a blocked artery in her chest. Results showed that she didnt however the ct scan showed the cancer had spread to her lungs and   was now at a stage 4. We met with the oncologist on Aug 12th ad he said he is going to continue the chemo and try to stave off the cancer but it cant be cured. He told me( not my wife) that she has 1 to 2 years to live. She is my life and she is so young ( 50) !  I need some advice as what to do to help her. I feel we should get another opinion however that means putting my beautiful wife through more tests.Plus I dont know if my wife will want another opinion. I have no one to talk to as my wife does not want me to talk to any family member about it. Both of her parents are now deceased and I am all she has. I really need some help as to what to do.   Please! map271 I am so sorry to hear that.  I too have stage IV breast cancer.  No doctor should give you a time line.  They don't know.  I have had so many tests, that you just get used to it.  Many have been treated for metestatic breast cancer and are surviving longer and longer. There are many comprehensive cancer centers out there that are available to help,  I have gone for second opinions and it has been to my benefit.  The first doctor gave me no time at all and that was 4 years ago.  I still have advanced breast cancer, but I actually am able to function quite well withe ongoing treatment.. A positive approach and positive support goes a long way.  There is more help out there.  I encourage you to look around even though it is a diffcult thing to cope with.  I wish you two all the best.
Posts.Title: 2nd stage breast cancer now 4th stage lung cancer

Posts.Content: On 1/19/2004 Mary Pat D. wrote: I have recently completed treatment for breast cancer that involved a lumpectomy, chemo and radiation. I am now on Arimidex for follow up treatment. My question to my doctor is...shouldn't I have a CT Scan to be certain the cancer is truly gone? Since it did spread to my lymph nodes, I cannot help but feel the need to know that it no longer exists in my body. Someone, other than my oncologist, told me I should have a CT scan just to be certain the cancer is gone. I feel the need for closure here, so I too would like a CT scan. However, my oncologist does not feel it is necessary. Has anyone else experienced this situation or have any advice for me in pursuing this matter further? Thanks... Mary Pat
Posts.Title: CT Scans - Necessary or Not
